65 years ago, 14-year-old Emmett Till was brutally murdered by white supremacists. This year, the Emmett Till Anti-lynching Act passed the House only to be blocked in the Senate. But we won't stop fighting—our bill making lynching a federal crime will become law.

As Americans across the country come together for the #VirtualMarchOnWashington, we give thanks for the generations of leaders who came before, and for all who are continuing the work to secure change today. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/EghP8YfXkAY6fip.jpg https://video.twimg.com/amplify_video/1299372618420760576/vid/480x270/mun2Pd_cpzrX1b8W.mp4?tag=13
We can start by passing @KamalaHarris and @CoryBooker's anti-lynching legislation to make lynching a federal crime for the first time in our history.

Emmett Till's murder is one of the worst moments in our history. But let's be clear: The racism and violence that shrouds his story still exist today. We have to keep fighting until we've dismantled systemic racism and white supremacy in every aspect of our economy and society.

Today, we will not only honor the memory of that march, but also carry on the struggle for racial justice.

“Hey guys, 
I’m back from DC.
Thought you would be interested ... 
Getting from the White House to my hotel room at the JW Marriott last night was quite a feat. Protesters everywhere.”

4/4 “...before the police made a barricade in front of the door with their bikes and bodies.  Guardian angels.

We need to be praying for DC and our country.”
